div3.head:
Health, health--
better than Gold !
div3.p:
Miss Mary Scofield, Preceptress, No. 630, Baltimore Street, Baltimore-- "Truth Stranger than Fiction."--This lady suffered for years with Chronic Inflammatory Rheumatism in its most malignant form.
She first contracted the disease when two years old, by being vaccinated with matter from a child who had the white swelling.
From this time to womanhood her sufferings were extreme — she never had relief from pain until cured by Hampton's Tincture.
[An Extract from the Letter.]

"I often wish my parents had known of this remedy when I was a child, as I believe I should have been saved the excruciating pain I have been subjected to, as well as the deformity of body I must carry to the grave, and my parents would not have been under such heavy expenses from doctors' bills and in sending me, as they did, to the celebrated Springs in England in search of health.
I wish all the afflicted world could see me and hear the benefits I have derived from this Tincture of Hampton's. I try to make all acquainted with its virtues with whom I come in contract.
"Gentlemen, I am a thousand times obliged to you, and you are at liberty to use my name and case to all.
"I remain yours in gratitude,

"No. 630 West Baltimore street."
Rheumatism, Cough, Dyspepsia, Debility, Scrofula, Eyes, Pain in the side, Back, &c., are cured by it.
Females and children.--This Tincture will be found a great medicine for all their diseases.
Call and get Pamphlets, and read many of the most powerful possible certificates of cures of the above diseases of our own citizens.

div3.head:

Southern
manufactures.
div3.p:
Do so, and especially if you can obtain as desirable Goods, without paying any more for them than their actual worth.
The
Woolen
Company,
of this city.

Organized last year, and in order to make such Goods as would not compete with, but would rather aid other Southern manufactures by furnishing grades and styles of Goods that have never heretofore been made in Virginia, they filled their Mill with machinery of the best and finest quality.
They are now manufacturing Fine Cassimeres and Cloths of every variety, from Virginia Merino and Mestizo Wool. and solicit the attention of the trade in the South to their Goods.
All who have seen their Army Cloths, manufactured at first expressly for the Virginia Military Institute, pronounce them at least equal, if not superior in quality, to those they had been buying heretofore, and quite as cheap.

The Virginia State and Central Agricultural Societies, at their Fair held in this city in October last, awarded to this Company a Gold Medal for their exhibition of Woolen Goods, which included some beautiful Shawls, Blankets, &c.

Purchasers may rely upon every piece of Goods manufactured by us being what it is represented, and under no circumstances will this Company be induced to work shoddy in their Goods, nor will they card any cotton with their wool.
Lewis D. Crenshaw, Pres't.
Samuel R. Mitchell, Directors.
Wellington Goddin, Directors.
John H. Montague, Directors.
P. W. Harwood, Directors.

Plain and Fancy Single and Double Milled Cassimeres and Cloths, besides a lot of Fine Blankets and gentlemen's Shawls — and are manufacturing at the rate of 4,000 yards per week; all of which we offer to the trade at fair prices and on liberal terms with entire confidence that the enterprise will receive a liberal support.

div3.head:
[from the Charleston (S. C.) Mercury.]
the cotton Boll.
by Henry Timrod.
[published by request.]

lg.l: Here, stretched at ease beneath
This immemorial pine,
Small sphere;
(By dusky fingers brought this morning here,
And shown with boastful smiles,)
I turn thy cloven sheath,
Through which the soft white fibres peer,
That, with their gossamer bands,
Unite, like love, the sea divided lands;
And slowly, thread by thread,
Draw forth the folded strands,
Than which the trembling line,
By whose frail help you startled spider fled
Down the tall spear grass from his swinging bed,
Is scarce more fine;
And as the tangled skein
Unravels in my hands,
Betwixt me and the noonday light,
A veil seems lifted, and for miles and miles
The landscape broadens on my sight,
As, in the little boll, there lurked a spell
Like that which, in the ocean shell,
With mystic sound,
Breaks down the narrow walls that hem us round,
And turns some city lane
Into the restless main,
With all his capes and isles!
Yonder bird
In those blue tracts above the thunder, where
No vapors cloud the stainless air,
And never sound is heard,
Unless at such rare time
When, from the City of the Blest,
Rings down some golden chime,
Sees not from his high place
So vast a cirque of summer space,
As widens round me in one mighty field
Which, rimmed by seas and sands,
Doth hall its earliest daylight in the beams
Of gray Atlantic dawns;
And, broad as realms made up of many lands,
Is lost afar
Behind the crimson hills and purple lawns
Of sunset, among plains which roll their streams
Against the Evening Star!

And lo!
to the remotest point of sight,
Although I gaze upon no waste of snows,
The endless field is white;
And the whole landscape glows,
For many a shining league away,
With such accumulated light
As Polar sands would flash beneath a tropic day!
Nor lack there (for the vision grows,
And the small charm within my hands,
More potent even than the fabled one,
Which oped whatever golden mystery
Lay hid in fairy wood or magic vale.--
The curious ointment of the Arabian tale,--
Beyond all mortal sense
Doth stretch my sight's horizon, and I see
Beneath its simple influence,
As if, with Uriel's crown,
I stood in some great temple of the Sun,
And looked, as Uriel, down!)
Nor lack there pastures rich and fields all green
With all the common gifts of God.
For temperate airs and torrid sheen
Weave Edens of the sod;
Through lands which look one sea of billowy gold.
Broad rivers wind their devious ways;
A hundred isles in their embraces fold
A hundred luminous bays;
And through yon purple haze
Vast mountains lift their plumed peaked, cloud-crowned;
And, save where up their sides the plowman creeps,
Great trackless forests gird them grandly round,
In whose dark shades a future navy sleeps!
Ye Stars, which though unseen, yet with me gaze
Upon this loveliest fragment of the earth!
Thou Sun, that kindliest all thy gentlest rays
Above it, as to light a favorite hearth!
Ye Clouds, that in your temples in the West
See nothing brighter than its humblest flowers!
And you, ye Winds, that on the ocean's breast
Are kissed to coolness ere ye reach its bowers!
Bear witness with me in my song of praise,
And tell the world that, since the world began,
No fairer land hath fired a poet's lays,
Or given a home to man!
But these are charms already widely blown!
His be the meed whose pencil's trace
Hath touched our very swamps with grace,
And round whose tuneful way
All Southern laurels bloom;
The Poet of "The Woodlands," unto whom
Alike are known
The flute's low breathing and the trumpet's tone,
And the soft west wind's sighs!
But who shall utter all the debt,
O. Land, wherein all powers are met
That bind a people's heart!
The world doth owe thee at this day,
And which it never can repay,
Yet scarcely deigns to own!
Where sleeps the poet who shall filly sing
The source wherefrom doth spring
That mighty commerce which, confined
To the mean channels of no selfish mart,
Goes out to every shore
Of this broad earth, and throngs the sea with ships,
That bear no thunders; hushes hungry lips
In alien lands;
Joins with a delicate web remotest strands
And, gladdening rich and poor,
Doth gild Parisian domes,
Or feed the cottage smoke of English homes,
And only bounds its blessings by mankind!
In offices like these, thy mission lies,
My Country, and it shall not end
As long as rain shall fall, and Heaven bend
In blue above thee; though thy foes be hard
And cruel as their weapons, it shall guard
Thy hearth-stones as a bulwark; make thee great
In white and bloodless state;
And haply, as the years increase,--
Still working through its humbler reach
With that large Wisdom which the Ages teach.--
Revive the half-dead dream of universal peace!
As men who labor in a mine
Beneath the deep Atlantic bed--
What time a storm is rolling overhead--
Hear the dull booming of the world of brine
Above them, and a mighty muffled roar
Of winds and waters, yet toil calmly on,
And split the rock, and pile the massive ore,
Or carve a niche, or shape the arched roof;
So I, as calmly, weave my woof
Of song, chanting the days to come,
Unsilenced, though the quiet summer air
Stirs with the bruit of battles; and each dawn
Wakes from its starry silence to the hum

Of many gathering armies.
Still,
In that we sometimes hear
Upon the Northern winds the voice of woe
Not wholly drowned in triumph, though I know
The end must crown us, and a few brief years
Dry all our tears,

I may not sing too gladly.
To Thy will

Resigned, O Lord!
we cannot all forget
That there is much even Victory must regret.
And, therefore, not too long
From the great burthen of our country's wrong
Delay our just release!
And, if it may be, save
These sacred fields of peace
From stain of patriot or of hostile blood!

Oh! help us, Lord!
to roll the crimson flood
Back on its course, and, while our banners wing

Northward, strike with us!
till the Goth shall cling
To his own blasted altar stones, and crave
Mercy; and we shall grant it, and dictate
The lenient future of his fate
There, where some rotting ships and crumbling quays
Shall one day mark the Port which ruled the Western Seas!

div3.head: A card.
div3.p: --to Mississippians.--The great and continued losses of everything valuable sent from home, and the want of storage for army supplies furnished by Benevolent Military Associations in Mississippi, have induced me to open a Depot in Richmond and another at Manassas, where I have erected a warehouse at the Manassas Depot.

In addition to the uses indicated, they are designed for offices of intelligence to the sick, their friends, recruits, or recovered invalids.
All boxes, packages, medicines, etc., sent from home, will be taken charge of and duly forwarded.
Please take notice of the following distinction:

All articles packed and designed for distribution should be forwarded, marked thus: "C. K. Marshall, Mississippi Depot, Richmond. " Then I can assort and appropriate as necessity requires.
But when a package is designed for specific uses, as goods for a given company or individuals, then address to my care, Mississippi Depot, Manassas. Always take and forward, by mail, receipts for all articles shipped.
The officers in the army interested in carrying out these plans can at all times keep me posted as to their locations.

Acting as Assistant Quartermaster, Army of Mississippi, I will attend to all orders from the proper officers for shoes, clothing, blankets, medicines, etc., etc., or to the procuring of clothing for the soldiers.
Respectfully, C. K. Marshall,
A. Q. M. Army Mississippi, and General Agent of

Mississippi Military Associations.
se 14--tf

div3.head:
Sequestration.
notice.
by the Receiver of the Eastern District of Virginia.
to all whom it may Concern.
div3.p:
I hereby notify every attorney, agent, former partner, trustee, or other person holding or controlling any lands, tenements or hereditaments, goods or chattels, rights or credits, or any interest therein, within the Eastern District of Virginia, of or for any alien enemy of the Confederate States of America, speedily to inform me, appointed Receiver for the said District, of the same; and to render to me an account thereof, and so far as is practicable to place the same in my hands.
Any such person willfully falling to do so, will be guilty of a high misdemeanor, and liable to be indicted, convicted, fined and imprisoned, as provided by law.

I also notify each and every citizen of the Confederate States speedily to give information to me (as he is required by law to do) of any and every lands, tenements and hereditaments, goods and chattels, rights and credits, within the said Eastern District of Virginia, and of every right and interest therein held, owned, possessed or enjoyed by or for any such alien enemy.
My office is on the Northern side of Main street, in the city of Richmond, between 10th and 11th streets. Thos. T. Giles,
Receiver for the Eastern District of Va.
se 13--d&cw2w

"R. L. I. B."
div3.p: Recruits wanted for the Richmond Light Infantry Blues.
Each recruit enters active service as soon as enlisted.

Any number of good Recruits will be received into this corps, permission having been obtained to increase the same to a complete battalion.
The Blues are attached to the Legion now in service in Western Virginia, under the command of Brigadier General Henry A. Wise.
The Blues are enlisted for the entire continuance of the war, and no recruit will be received for a less period of enlistment.
Apply to Capt. Hammond Duncan, Wise Legion Office, over P. H. Taylor's Music Store, No. 188 Main street, between 9th and 10th, Richmond, between the hours of 9 A. M. and 6 P. M.
None need apply but men of good character and robust health.
Honorary members of the Blues, and other friends throughout the country, are requested to assist us.
Uniforms and other necessary clothing furnished.

div3.head:
Medical College of Virginia.
session of 1861-'62.
div3.p: The next annual course of Lectures will commence on the first Monday in November, 1861, and continue until the 1st of March ensuing.
Charles Bell Gibson, M. D., Professor of Surgery.
David H. Tucker, M. D., Professor of Theory and Practice of Medicine.
Beverley R. Wellford, M. D., Professor of Material Medical and Therapeutics.
A. E. Peticolas, M. D., Professor of Anatomy.
L. S. Joynes, M. D., Professor of Institutes of Medicine, &c.
James H. Conway, M. D., Professor of Obstetrics, &c.
James B. McCAW, M. D., Professor of Chemistry.
Marion Howard, M. D., Demonstrator of Anatomy.

Under a liberal appropriation of the State Legislature, the means of instruction have been much improved.
Numerous and valuable additions have been made to the Chemical Apparatus and Anatomical Museum.
New illustrations have been added to the former stock in every department, and a new Hospital, constructed on the best plan, has been for several months in successful operation.
During the continuance of the present war, the clinical advantages offered by Richmond will be invaluable.

Two prizes, of $50 each, are offered to members of the graduating class; First, for the best essay on any subject pertaining to the theory or practice of medicine; secondly, for the best essay on any subject of surgery or obstetrics.
Fees--To each Professor, $15; Demonstrator of Anatomy, $10; Matriculation, $5; Graduation, $25.
For further information, or a copy of the catalogue, address L. S. Joynes, M. D.,
Dean of the Faculty.
Richmond, Aug. 28, 1861. se 9--M&Th6w

div3.head: University of Virginia.
div3.p: --The next session of this institution will commence on the 1st day of October, and continue until the ensuing 4th of July.

The exercises in the Academic, law and Medical Schools will be continued as heretofore, and the Board of Visitors will meet on the 10th inst. for the purpose of organizing a School of Military and Civil Engineering and Tactics, to go into operation at the beginning of the session.

The extensive military hospital established within a few hundred yards of the University, and of which two of the Professors in the Medical School are attending Surgeons, will afford unusual advantages for clinical instruction to medical students.
For catalogues, address S. Maupin,
se 6--1m Chairman of the Faculty.

div3.head: Vaccine Virus.
div3.p:
--The Medical Men throughout the State, whether in or out of the Army, are respectfully requested to forward all the reliable Vaccine Virus they can spare to this office.--Compliance with this request is urged upon their attention as of utmost importance to the public welfare.
A. E. Peticolas, M. D.,
au 28--1m* Vaccine Agent.

div3.head: Estray Mare.
div3.p:
--On Saturday last a Bay Mare escaped from the subscriber in Manchester, and has not since been found.
She was about 10 years old, rather under size, has one white hind foot, and a saddle knot or lump on her back.
When she escaped she had on a saddle and bridle.
A liberal reward will be paid for her delivery at Blankinship's Stable, on Franklin street.
se 14--4t* M. W. Michaux.

div3.head: Strayed
div3.p:
--On Tuesday morning, a grey Mule.
The hair is rubbed off his breast.
A liberal reward will be given on his delivery to
Henry C. Buren,
se 14--3t* Head of Broad street.

div3.head: Estray.
div3.p:
--Taken up, on my farm, on the Brooke Turnpike, three miles from the city of Richmond, on the 11th day of September, 1861, a speckled grey Horse, from 10 to 12 years old, and about five feet high; no marks visible.
The owner of said Horse is requested to come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take him away.
Henry Bruns.
Henrico, Sept. 12, 1861. se 13--3t*

div3.head: Lost
div3.p:
--Last week, a white Pointer Bitch Puppy, about four months old, with black cars.
A reward will be paid for her delivery to
Dr. Burwell,
se 13--3t* Corner of Leigh and 6th sts.

div3.head: Lost
div3.p:
--On last Sunday night, between the Powhatan Hotel and the First Presbyterian Church, a small double-case Gold Watch, with a black cord attached.
The finder, by leaving it at this office, or at the Powhatan Hotel, so that the owner can obtain it, will be suitably rewarded.

div3.head: Five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from my residence, on Clay street, three squares above Brooke Avenue, a medium- sized Red Cow. Had, when she left home, a bell on, with a double belt and a homemade buckle, made of wire, on the same; she had also a scar on one of her sides, as though it was done with a heavy whip; or it might have been by another cow's horn.
I will give the above reward if delivered to me, or such information so that I can get her. [se 2--ts] H. R. Cronie.

div3.head: Ran away
div3.p:
--On the 2d Sept., from my garden, on the Brook Road, in Henrico county, a Negro Boy named Tom, about 15 years of age, mulatto color, slender make, and countenance indicating delicate health.
Has had some experience as a cook, and is probably so employed at one of the camps near the city.
He had on when last seen a black coat and grey pants; the latter had been shortened, and had a seam around each leg, five or six inches below the knee.
A reward of $5 will be paid for his apprehension.
Information being left at this office.
C. Chamberlain,

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p:
--From the subscriber, a few days since, a deaf and dumb Negro man. Said negro is black, stout built, 5 feet 6 inches high, has one front tooth out, and has a wart on his forehead.
He was raised in Virginia, and the last heard of him he was making his way for that State.
A liberal reward will be paid for his arrest.
W. P. Pope,
Wilmington, N. C., Sept. 5, 1861. se 10--6t

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on the 6th instant, at Vienna, Virginia, a Mulatto Boy named Sam. Said Boy is about 20 years of age, 5 feet 5 or 6 inches high.
He had on when he left a pair of white oznaburg pants and a checked shirt; no coat; is rather slow spoken; no particular marks remembered.

The above reward will be given for sufficient proof to convict any white person of assisting said Boy in affecting his escape; or twenty-five dollars will be paid for his safe delivery either to myself or in any jail where I can get him.
A. K. Tribble.
au 27--1m* Of the 3d Reg't S. C. Vols.

div3.head: Removal of Briggs' Old established bakery.
div3.p: The subscriber, thankful for the patronage so liberally bestowed on him for the last five years, takes this method of informing his friends and the public in general, that he has removed to the corner below his old stand, which he has had fitted up in the most approved style, and second to none south of Mason and Dixon's line, where he hopes to meet his old friends and the public, assuring them that nothing shall be wanting on his part to please them. --Having increased facilities, he will now be able to serve all that will favor him with a call with as good Bread, Cakes, Crackers and Pies, as can be made in any establishment in the city.
Bread, Rolls, Buns, Biscuits, &c., fresh every morning and evening.
Cakes, Crackers and Pies, fresh every day
Bread, Cakes and Crackers nicely packed and sent to any part of the city or country.

Parties supplied with Plain and Ornamental Cakes.

His wagons are so constructed as to be water and air-tight.
His boxes can be found at Duval & Norton's, corner 11th and Main streets and Johnston & Millspaugh's, on Main, between 17th and 18th streets. All orders left at the above places, will be promptly attended to.

div3.head: Attention, Militia.
div3.p: --Order No. 1.--The 5th Company of the 33d Regiment of Virginia Militia (the bounds of whose district extends from the suburbs of the city to Brook Run, and from Mechanicsville to Brook Turnpike,) will meet at their usual muster ground, near Wade's store, at 2 o'clock P. M., on Monday, 16th inst., for the purpose of electing a Captain and other commissioned officers.
div3.closer: By order of Frank Dickman, se 12--4t* Lieut. Commanding.

div3.head: Notice.

list.item: I.--Persons who are sending clothing and supplies to troops in the field, are requested to mark distinctly on the package (with marking ink) the name of the party for whom intended, the Regiment to which he belongs, and the place of destination, care of Quartermaster at Richmond, to whom the usual railroad receipt should be forwarded by the shipper.

II.--Many packages arrive at the depots of the railroads in Richmond with paper marks rubbed off; of course their destination cannot be known by the Quartermaster.
Others are imperfectly marked, and cannot be identified.
III.--All articles deposited at the Quartermaster's Office in Richmond, for shipment, must be left there before 3 o'clock, P. M., to insure their shipment on that day.

div3.closer:
J. Maury Garland,
au 23--ts Capt. and Ass't Q. M.

div3.head:
Confederate States of America,
Department of State,
Richmond, Sept. 4, 1861.
div3.p: Proposals to do the Printing and Binding of the Department of State.--Sealed proposals to do the Printing and Binding of the Department of State--specifying the price of composition, rule and figure work, press work, and binding, and the price of paper when called on to furnish it — will be received at the Department until Tuesday morning, the 10th instant, on which day the proposals will be opened and the contracts awarded.
The Department will not be bound to accept the lowest bid.
No bid will be accepted however, in which the proposed prices exceed those specified in the act of Congress in relation to "Public Printing," approved February 27, 1861.

Bidders will be required to furnish two good and sufficient sureties for the faithful performance of their contract.
Wm. M. Browne,
se 5--t10S Acting Secretary of State.
